questions.title: What is perspective taking?
questions.description: Perspective taking is when we try to see a situation from someone else’s point-of-view, or we “put ourselves in their shoes”. Each person has their own unique perspective!

questions.question: What affects how we see a situation?

questions.title: All of the above!
questions.description: We all see a situation differently, based on our own feelings, experiences, beliefs, cultures, and much more! We should consider these influences when trying to understand another person's perspective.

questions.question: How can we try to understand someone's feelings during a specific situation? Try to put these steps in order!

choices.answer: Think about the situation from their perspective
Reflect on similar experiences that you have had
Remember how these similar experiences made you feel
Realize this might be how they are feeling too!

questions.title: The process of perspective taking
questions.description: We can think about the situation from their perspective and reflect on similar experiences that we have had (and how they made us feel). This can help us understand how they might be feeling too.

questions.title: Let's practice!
questions.description: Let's practice perspective taking! Remember, we might react to the same situation in different ways based on our unique backgrounds.

questions.title: Meet Sanjay!
questions.description: Sanjay is 9 years old, and he lives in a small town surrounded by beautiful mountains. Animals are very important to Sanjay's culture and are never eaten as food. His family only eats vegetables and fruits that they grow on their farm.

questions.question: How do you think Sanjay feels about a delicious beef stew?

choices.answer: Yum! Sanjay is excited for the beef stew.
No, thank you! Sanjay doesn't want the beef stew.

questions.title: No, thank you!
questions.description: Animals are very important in Sanjay's culture, and his family only eats fruits and vegetables grown on their farm. He probably doesn't want a beef stew, but is there a salad instead?

questions.question: What's your perspective on beef stew?

choices.answer: Nah, I don't like beef stew.
I'm not sure...but I'll try it!

questions.title: Great job!
questions.description: We might have different feelings about the same food, such as beef stew. We can still understand each other's perspective if we remember a time that someone offered us a food that we did (or didn't) like or want to try.

questions.title: Back to Sanjay!
questions.description: Two years ago, Sanjay's sister was badly hurt and rushed to the hospital. Sanjay was there too, and remembers everything the doctor did to help his sister. Since then, he has always wanted to become a doctor.

questions.question: How do you think Sanjay would feel about visiting the doctor?

choices.answer: Oh, no! Sanjay would feel scared.
Eh...Sanjay doesn't really care about doctors.

questions.title: Sanjay would be excited!
questions.description: Sanjay wants to be a doctor when he grows up, since he remembers how a doctor helped his sister. This might be a good learning opportunity for him, so he's probably excited!

questions.question: What's your perspective on visiting the doctor?

questions.title: Great job!
questions.description: We might have different reactions to the same situation, such as visiting the doctor. We can still understand each other's perspective if we consider that everyone might have different past experiences with doctors.

questions.title: Take a moment to pause and reflect
questions.description: Think about a time when you disagreed with someone. How could you use perspective taking in this situation?

questions.title: You are a superstar!
questions.description: Remember, we don't always have to agree with each other. But perspective taking helps us understand each other's thoughts, feelings, and actions.
